summary: This is a stipulation filed with the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, agreeing to dismiss with prejudice the appeal (No. 19-2221-er) of Jeffrey Epstein. The parties, represented by their counsel, agree that the appeal will be dismissed and cannot be reinstated, with each side bearing its own costs.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual whose criminal appeal is being dismissed with prejudice by stipulation of the parties.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Attorney who signed the stipulation on behalf of Jeffrey Epstein, agreeing to dismiss the appeal.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney listed as counsel for Jeffrey Epstein on the stipulation document.

connections.description: Weingarten is listed as counsel representing Epstein in the appeal being dismissed.
Weinberg is listed as counsel representing Epstein in the appeal being dismissed.
Both are listed as counsel for the defendant-appellant, indicating they are part of the same legal defense team.

events.title: Dismissal of Epstein's Appeal
events.description: The appeal (No. 19-2221-er) filed by Jeffrey Epstein in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is dismissed with prejudice by stipulation of the parties.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's appeal (No. 19-2221-er) in the Second Circuit Court of Appeals was dismissed with prejudice in August 2019.
The dismissal was by stipulation, meaning both Epstein's counsel and the U.S. government agreed to end the appeal.
Once dismissed with prejudice, the appeal cannot be reinstated.
Each party bore its own costs, expenses, and fees.
